DATE FOR MERDEKA TALKS


    1. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Chief Minister whether he is in a position to give the House information about a fixed date for the commencement of the Merdeka Talks.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, no definite date has been finalised, but, on present indication, the talks will be resumed probably towards the end of February.

REGISTERED LIMITED COMPANIES, SINGAPORE
(1955 Profits)


    2. Mr D. S. Marshall asked the Financial Secretary to give -

    (a) the number of Limited Companies registered in Singapore and the total profits made by them in 1955;

    (b) the number thereof who in 1955 made a profit exceeding 10 per cent of their capital, and the total of such profits.

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, the number of private limited companies registered in Singapore at the end of 1955 was 1,344. The number of public limited companies registered in Singapore at the end of 1955 was 127.

    Private limited companies are not required to submit accounts and balance sheets to the Registrar of Companies and no information is available as to the profits which these companies made in 1955. Public limited companies are required to submit accounts and balance sheets to the Registrar of Companies. I regret, however, that shortage of time and preoccupation with other urgent matters has made it impossible for me to collect and digest the information which the hon. Member requires about these companies. If he wishes to pursue the matter, perhaps the hon. Member may care to obtain the information from the Registrar of Companies himself.

    Mr Marshall: Sir, the question is one of public importance. I would ask if the Financial Secretary would consider giving the answers for the record of this House, obtaining for the private companies their profits from the Income Tax Department, and for the public companies their profits from the Registrar of Companies, and making them part of the record for the next sitting in December.

    Mr Hart: As regards private companies, Sir, I regret I can give no such assurance. Private companies do submit information as to their profits to the Comptroller of Income Tax, but under section 6 of the Ordinance, the consent of the Governor is required before that information can be divulged.

Column: 834



    With regard to the profits of public companies, I will endeavour to provide the hon. Member with the information which he requires by the 5th of December.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, the Income Tax Ordinance precludes the divulgence of information about individual returns. The public are entitled to information on a global scale which would not pinpoint individual firms. I would ask if the Financial Secretary would reconsider his reply and give us an assurance that he will look into the question of giving us the information about the profits of private companies on the 5th of December?

    Mr Hart: I must have notice of that question, Sir.

CUSTOMS EXAMINATION
(Train Delays)


    3. Mr John Ede asked the Financial Secretary whether he is aware of the long delays caused to passenger trains travelling between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur due to customs examination at Johore Bahru; and whether he will arrange with the Federation authorities for Federation customs officers to board trains at Singapore Railway Station so that the examination can be carried out en route.

    Mr T. M. Hart: The hon. Member will be interested to know that the two Governments have already agreed in principle that Federal customs officers should board trains in Singapore and make customs examinations en route to Johore Bahru. A Bill which, amongst other things, will authorise this to be done is at present in draft and will be introduced as soon as possible.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $10 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 10 (1) , Administration-City Services, on page 33 of the Estimates.

    The Chairman: I am not quite certain whether the hon. Member is talking about economy. Is he making the point that he wishes that certain economies should be effected in this vote?

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, if I can get a clear explanation from the Financial Secretary and if I am satisfied with his explanation, I may withdraw my amendment. It is not a question of economy. The question is how this figure - an increase of $24,000 - is arrived at.

    The Chairman: It occurs to me then that there was no necessity for the hon. Member to file a motion on the amendment because Standing Order 69 (11) says:

    "On any question in the Committee of Supply debate shall be confined to the policy of the service for which the money is to be provided...".

Therefore, if the hon. Member wished to debate the policy of the service for which the money is required, then, of course, his duty was to file a motion in the way of an amendment, but if it was just to get information, then the proper procedure would have been to wait until the Main Question was proposed and then questions could have been asked, as have, in fact, been asked under Head 1. If the hon. Member will indicate whether or not he is attacking the policy, then, of course, he can continue.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: I am much obliged, Mr Chairman. If the explanation from the Financial Secretary is satisfactory, then I will withdraw my amendment, as you have indicated that there is no question of filing a motion; but if the explanation is not satisfactory,

and I am not satisfied with the amount that is involved, then I will, as an indication of my protest, move an amendment to reduce that figure.

Member will no doubt remember that in the course of this year we took a supplementary provision to meet the increased cost of current consumption arising from the air-conditioning of these Courts. It has worked out at $2,000 a month, and the total required in 1957 is therefore estimated at $24,000. The extra $3,600 is required for other City Services.

    Mr Marshall: If it please you, Sir, this Assembly has notice of a question by Mr Sutherland regarding the appointment of further Judges. Sir, the question of the appointment of additional Judges has been a matter of urgency for some months. In fact, this goes back to the beginning of this year, and it is only the reluctance to appoint Malayans who are qualified, available, seasoned, experienced people as Judges that is holding up these appointments. Sir, in the inter-Party talks for the purposes of the constitutional conference in London, it was apparent that there was a division of views as to the propriety of Malayanisation of the judiciary. I would like to say for myself and for my Party that we are deeply convinced that it is a matter of vital importance that the security of tenure of the Judges

Column: 838

should in no way be broached. Sir, we may prefer to have our own men who understand our ways as Judges, but we do recognise that for decades the expatriate officials who have acted as Judges have maintained a tradition and an integrity which have been an inspiration not only to members of the Bench in the lower Courts, not only to the Bar, but to the whole population who respect and admire this administration of justice. In the circumstances, if only as an expression of our gratitude for the evolution and maintenance of this very high tradition, we should not in any way interfere with the security of tenure which they enjoy. But I must add this, Sir: that if this colonial reluctance to the appointment of local men as Judges is pursued by forcing upon the country further expatriate Judges, then the position may well be endangered and I, for one, would deeply regret it. I would plead with the Chief Minister to use his influence with the Governor to see that the harmony which exists between the people and the judiciary should in no way be upset by unwise appointments which go contrary to the feelings of the people. Our people are a decent people, Sir, and their attitude is a simple one, namely, that what has been done has been done. The officials appointed have done a good job of `work. Let us not interfere with them, but do not appoint more expatriates. It is time we were given a chance. If you appoint more expatriate officials with the possibility that this country will have for the next 15 or 20 years expatriate Judges, then the question of Malayanisation must become an acute, a topical and a necessary one.

    Sir, I would plead that the Governor be informed of the view that I believe the people of Singapore hold - that it would be inappropriate at this juncture of our development to ignore the experienced, seasoned legal men we have who could be appointed to the posts of honour and responsibility of Judges, and that it would be wrong to appoint further expatriates as Judges, not only because it would go contrary to our wishes, which may or may not matter to the Governor, but it would go contrary to the interests of the judiciary

Column: 839

who are now in existence. This, I have no doubt, is a matter of considerable importance to the Governor. I would plead that a practical and sensible approach to the people's wishes be considered and that colonial powers should lot be exercised to ride roughshod not only over our interests but over the permanent interests of the judiciary themselves.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Sir, everyone will agree with the expression of views given by the Member for Cairnhill, but he has forgotten to do one thing. He has forgotten to put down a token vote of $10 in the Estimates for the appointment of a local Judge. Sir, I move that.

    Mr Marshall: Sir, I have to get the Governor's permission.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: The Member for Cairnhill can do it now.

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Chairman, Sir, during the conference in London our Party also stood firm on the question of the judiciary, that Judges should be accorded the respect which they have enjoyed all these years and that they should be independent of every political Party. We are convinced that no politics should be allowed to influence any appointment to the judiciary because in the Judges are entrusted the security and the future of a country. So far we can say with pride that our Judges have always won our admiration, and for their work we are grateful, and we should all give support to see that there should be permanency of tenure for those who are already on the Bench. But I do agree that the public at large and the Bar are very much concerned about the delay in appointing additional Judges. I am told that some of the civil cases in Court have to wait for as long as six to eight months before they can be heard. This state of affairs cannot be tolerated and I would urge the Governor and the Government to consider the appointment of additional Judges without further delay. Among our local serving officers in the legal service there

Column: 840

are a number of very able men who have proved themselves to be above temptation and fit to carry out the work of High Court Judges. I would urge that consideration be given for the appointment of our local legal officers as Judges.

    Mr R. C. H. Lim (Nominated): Mr Chairman, there is a saying that "Justice should not only be done but justice should also be shown to be done." Following this wise statement, Sir, I would like to suggest that the salaries of Judges be taken out of the annual Estimates and be a charge on the revenue.

    The Chief Secretary (Mr W. A. C. Goode): Sir, the Member for Paya Lebar referred to alleged delays which take place in the High Court. I am sure he will have noted with satisfaction that in the Estimates which are now before us there is provision for the appointment of an additional Judge in order to bring the courts up to date with their work; and previously this Assembly approved additional appointments of Court reporters so that the reporting side of the Courts could also keep pace with the volume of work. I understand, Sir, that there has been a considerable improvement in the pace with which the Courts are keeping up with the cases presented to them, but there is still a further backlog to be made up. I hope that if we get a new judge appointed early in the new year there will no longer be cause for dissatisfaction with the speed with which justice can be obtained in Singapore.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Chairman, Sir, at the present time Judges are appointed by Her Majesty by Letters Patent under the Public Seal issued in pursuance of instructions from Her Majesty through the Secretary of State.

    The Member for Cairnhill knows that the question of the judiciary was a matter for discussion with the Secretary of State during the last talks. I can assure him that this is still a matter which will be discussed when the constitutional talks are resumed in London next year.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, I see on page 36, sub-head 2 (5) , that an amount of $48,000 is provided for the Council of Ministers for telegrams alone. This works out to be $4,000 a month for telegrams. This estimate of $48,000 to be spent on telegrams alone is either fantastic or an extravagance on the part of the Government. I wonder if this amount could be reduced. Sir, $30,000 was provided for this year and with this amount we were able to cope with telegrams for the Merdeka talks between Singapore, the United Kingdom and the rest of the other places. Sir, the delegation for next year's Merdeka talks will be a very small one and will not be equivalent to the size of the delegation which went to London this year. I wonder why there should be an increase of $18,000 on telegrams.

    Mr Marshall: Mr Chairman, Sir, I must confess, as the former Chief Minister, I am more than astonished at the figure of $48,000 for telegrams. I do not believe I spent even a thousand dollars in more than a year. I am told that we spent $38,000 for telegrams for the Merdeka mission. I was shocked to the core when I read that in a newspaper cutting which I received in Japan. Let me assure you, Sir, that as far as I was concerned, I did not spend $100 on telegrams for the Merdeka talks, and I can only assume that these were telegrams sent by the Public Relations Officer to the Colonial Secretary and to the Governor - long screeds and reports of what was appearing in newspaper editorials in this territory which could well be condensed. The Chief Minister received copies of those telegrams which were sent to the Colonial Secretary and

to the Governor. But this is an extravagance, I completely agree, and I do agree that this $48,000 could be almost completely axed.

    Mr Hart: Sir, I think the Member for Queenstown has forgotten that we took a Supplementary Vote for this service last year. Perhaps, to refresh his memory, I may be allowed to read from col. 178 in Hansard of the 7th of September:

    "As means of communication develop, so one tends to use them. The habit has grown steadily over the years to communicate by telegram and radiogram. It saves much time and, I think, leads to greater efficiency and the speedier despatch of Government business. The practice is common not only in Government but also in business and other circles. Following this growing habit, Government expenditure on telegrams has tended to increase. Expenditure over the past five years has been as follows: 1952, $l2,000; 1953, $19,000; 1954, $23,000; 1955, $38,000; from 1st January to 9th August, 1956, $32,000. The considerable increase in 1956 over 1955 figures has been due, in the main, to increased communication on constitutional matters in the early part of this year. The original vote has now been expended and a supplement of $30,000 is asked for. This estimate was made in early June on the basis of average monthly expenditure in the first part of the year. There has been a slight falling off in expenditure since that date but the application has been kept to the same level in order to cover all possible contingencies in the future. There has been no extravagance in expenditure. Telegrams are despatched to all quarters of the globe and cover the multifarious business of Government."

    Expenditure at the present time is running to the order of $4,850 a month and, on that basis, it would be necessary to ask for $48,000 for the coming year. There will be increased communication in connection with the Merdeka talks which will take place in February and no doubt afterwards there will be further need to communicate by telegram. Every possible effort is made to send communications to the Colonial Office and by the Colonial Office to this Government by seamail, but in many cases time is saved and the business of the Government is discharged much more efficiently if telegrams are used.

    I regret that I have no notice of the remarks which the Member for Cairnhill made about the cost of telegrams in connection with the last Merdeka talks. A considerable sum of money was spent

by the Public Relations Officer in sending precis of the news items which appeared in the local Press to the Chief Minister. My understanding of the matter was that they were sent specifically by the Public Relations Officer to enable the Chief Minister to be fully aware of the reactions of the public in Singapore to the progress of the talks.

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Hart: That is probably true because no doubt numerous copies were made and copies were sent to every Member of the delegation.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: May I raise one small point, Sir? The Hon. the Financial Secretary said just now that sea-mail takes a lot of time, but may I draw his attention to the fact that today's air services take only 48 hours?     Mr Hart: No, Sir. I do apologise. When I said "seamail", I meant to include airmail as well. Bags do go to the Colonial Office by courier and all communications which we can send by airmail are sent in these bags; but the fact of the matter is that telegrams can arrive in the Colonial Office in a very few hours after despatch from here.     Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, it is a real pity that my motion to reduce this vote was not received in time for today's debate, and I cannot move an amendment to reduce this amount.     Mr R. Jumabhoy: Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $10 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 8, Passages and Miscellaneous Travelling Expenses, on page 53 of the Estimates.

    Sir, there is no explanation given as to how the figure of $1,600,000 is being spent and on whom. Are these passages by air or by sea; how many are air passages and how many are by sea; how many of these are for Europeans and how many for Asians? I think this is a colossal sum. I think at least $200,000 or $300,000 could be saved if the heaven- born go by sea instead of by air. Sir, because money is insufficient, we are to be taxed heavily, and the Press reports that the Government carries the day without mentioning with the help of official and nominated votes when it comes to voting on any item. With whose votes does it carry the day, Sir? With the three ex-officios and four nominated Members, of course. What I am asking here, Sir, is: Why cannot these people go by sea instead of by air so that a lot of money can be saved?

    Question proposed.

    Mr Goode: Sir, this figure under "Passages" is a very large figure indeed and I am not surprised that it has provoked comment from hon. Members opposite. I am afraid I cannot give him a detailed breakdown between the heaven-born, the lower-born and the medium-born, but I can give him two or three points which may help to explain the figure.

    First, it is not only to provide passages for European officers whose passages are, of course, provided as part of their conditions of service and, speaking for the majority of those officers, I do not think they have any wish to be made to travel by air. I think they all prefer to have the longer holiday and travel

Column: 847

by sea, perhaps even more so in present circumstances. But the hard fact is that the demands of the public service very frequently make it necessary that an officer, who would prefer to have a leisurely three weeks' voyage by sea, be asked to travel by air so that he may return to his duty earlier.

    Another point of information that I would like to make is that this sum is not exclusively spent on expatriate officers enjoying their generous conditions of service. A very substantial part of this money goes to meet the cost of sending officers and others from Singapore to attend conferences and other occasions overseas. I think hon. Members will be aware that in the last year - in fact, in recent years - we have more and more taken the opportunity of sending our officers, particularly our local officers, overseas to attend conferences and international meetings where we hope that not only will they profit by attending these meetings but that they may be able to contribute to them. If the hon. Member would like a more detailed breakdown, I will endeavour to get it and provide it for him.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Chairman, Sir, it is a popular misunderstanding that to travel by sea, in the case of officers going on home leave, is cheaper than by air. I remember this question was thrashed out years back in the City Council. Sir, what actually happens is that air passages in many cases nowadays are much cheaper than first-class sea passages.

    Secondly, Sir, when you send an officer by sea, he takes, say, 25 days to reach the United Kingdom and the same period to come back, and during all that time - 50 days in all - he is being paid a salary and he does not have to do any work. In fact, I think he likes to go by sea. But if you pay a hundred dollars or so extra to get him to travel by air, then you will be able to get work out of him for the number of days that are saved by his travelling by air.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, the Hon. the Chief Secretary has just told me that he will be glad to give me a detailed breakdown of the figure of $1,600,000. If I

remember correctly, Sir, in past Legislatures I have been informed that air travel by officers going on leave cost over $150,000 more than travel by sea. I would like, however, to go into the details at leisure with the Hon. the Chief Secretary. In the meantime, my amendment stands.
